title: What makes a student a teacher's favorite? - Quora

response.answer_text: If you're in school, you spend most of your day in class with your teachers. If your teacher doesn't like you, or you don't get along, school can be extra difficult. Getting on your teacher's good side doesn't just mean getting good grades and sucking up, though. To be in the good books of your teacher you can follow the given steps and make your school life experience more fun and effective: Ask meaningful questions in class. Asking questions shows that you care about the subject matter. It also shows that you’re paying attention. Asking questions is a great indicator of intelligence and a desire to learn.Complete all assignments on time. This one can be difficult if you have a lot of work, or if you tend to procrastinate. However, turning in assignments on time shows your teacher that you are prioritizing their class.Make extra efforts in your work. It’s always good to do more than the bare minimum for an assignment. Extra efforts can include binding your paper in a nice way to make it more presentable, or doing extra research for an assignment.Ask for extra help if you need it. Asking for help shows your teacher that you want to succeed. Many teachers look for this quality in a student, because if you want to succeed you’re likely to take their help and suggestions seriously.Respect the teacher’s authority on a subject. Teachers have been through a lot of education and they have chosen a profession where they get to share their knowledge. You may know a lot about a subject as well, but teachers will appreciate if you treat them as the experts they are.Let your teacher know who you are. Teachers can tell when a student isn’t being themselves. Never try to hide those things just to look like the perfect student.Be helpful to your teacher. Teaching can be difficult, and teachers get tired, just like you. If you notice that your teacher could use a hand, offer to help out. They’ll definitely notice and appreciate your helpful attitude.I hope the information provided by me would be helpful for students to make their school life more productive and become teacher’s favorite.

There's a difference between a good student who makes teaching so rewarding, a bad student, who is a class management nightmare, and a favorite student.I won't add anything new to the excellent comments other than my own experiences. My favorites could be a scruffy lost soul one year, and a braggadocios little snot the next year. I can't quantify who tugs at your heart, but what I always sensed was that they needed me more than the others. I don't know if it's done everywhere, but years ago when I was teaching fourth grade, all of the third and fourth grade teachers would meet at a table and talk about kids. Ack!!!! How terrible! In a tiny town there's a history and background knowledge that can support and enhance the learning experience for kids. The discussion would go something like this...Third grade teacher."James is from a broken home, he was out of school for months last year, but he's really a tough cookie and bright. He has a knack for stealing little things." Fourth grade teacher, "Is he Mary's boy? I had her older son a few years back. I have a history with her. I'll take him."Third grade teacher...."Annie's a chatterbox, she'll drive you nuts." Fourth grade teacher.."Is there anyone she shouldn't be in class with?" Third grade teacher..."Diane! Don't put them together! They'll talk nonstop!" Fourth grade teacher.."I'll take them both. They could be my movers and shakers this year!"Are you following this? As we've all stated many times, teachers are human and like and dislike as others do. Matching to the teacher's personality can be just as positive and productive. Some teachers are mother figures, others strict rulers, others easy going, and some, like me, in the middle. P.S. I love, love, love a kid with a sense of humor!!!

Number one, don't try too hard. I don't like when students are buttering me up with false flattery to try to gain favor. Just be yourself. Smile and be pleasant in class, but don't overdo it. Do what you are asked to do. Study, do your homework, be prepared for class, interact with the class and the teacher when appropriate. Give your best effort to do well in class. Show interest in knowing the subject being taught and seek to truly understand the underlying concepts as well as the procedures. Ask how the concepts being taught connect to previous lessons and what will be coming in the future so you can link your current knowledge to future learning. Seek help of you need it. If you do understand a concept, offer to help other students understand. Teachers like to know they are helping their students. If the lesson taught was helpful tip you, let the teacher know. If something the teacher did was confusing or did not help you, describe what was confusing and ask for clarification. The teacher can then adapt their lesson to correct this issue in the future. Constructive feedback is always welcome for this teacher. “That sucked. I don't get it.” is not constructive. Be specific and positive about what you didn't understand and what you think would help you to understand. Teachers are human just like everyone else. We like to be liked. Be an open and true person, and we will respond in kind. One last don't. Especially if your teacher is the opposite sex, be very careful to not do anything that can be construed as a sexual invitation by ANYONE. Getting too close to a student can ruin a teachers reputation, career and life. Even if it is completely innocent, it can haunt a teacher. Listen to Sting’a song “Don't Stand So Close To Me.”

ARE YOU A TEACHER’S PET ? Is as good as asking ...… As a student, were YOU a problematic child ?????  I am not making this answer based on the wisdom of sages. What I am about to say is based on my experience of more than 50 years, as a teacher. The students, (who are brilliant; who are extraordinarily brilliant;) are good enough to goad the teachers to out-perform themselves while teaching in the class. They were so intelligent, that I have seen teachers’ knees SHAKING IN THEIR PANTS WHEN THESE STUDENTS RAISED THEIR HANDS TO ASK A QUESTION. But when they left school, they were gone for ever and ever. They neither came to school thereafter; nor in the personal life of the teachers concerned.  On the other hand, the problematic students - are the real headache creators, for the teachers. But there is a plus-point with them. They are the real touch-stone to test the mettle (the true worth) of which the teacher is made. They are the ones, who make this profession really worthy. Invariably, I had these problematic students ….. in every succeeding batch, year after year. I tried the best, that was in me, to get them to right track. I did succeed; but not always. There were some really hard-cores, totally adamant to change. Even to this day, (when they have become grand-fathers), they are their teacher’s pet .

I think it is unexplainable. You love who you love. But a kid who is kind , respectful, polite and considerate is hard not to love. A kid like that who tries and especially if they try hard and are successful, a teacher has to carefully walk the line of encouragement and not letting the rest of the kids how grateful you are to have that kid in your class. Of course any time you have one of those epiphany moments with a student and see the light turn on with their new understanding, it reminds and reinforces the reason that you teach in the first place. That develops a love that really lasts for a student. Every coach is waiting for a student who's talent makes them look good. Sometimes it is the kid whose parents are most involved with the classroom or program, unfortunately sometimes it is the kid whose parents throw the most money around.

I think the best way to explain this is by acknowledging that teachers are real people with real emotions. Like everyone else, there are some people whom we connect with more deeply than others. Sometimes, there’s an occasional person whom we don’t like. *As a disclaimer, a teacher should always treat every student with respect and without favoritism*. However, teachers like students who can connect with them on a personal level. Maybe the teacher and student have the same sense of humor, went through a similar upbringing, or are fans of the same band. And, like most other people, teachers get attached to students who share a connection. I know many teachers who keep in touch with former students, and it brings many, if not all teachers, joy to see students succeed on their own paths of life. In conclusion, get to know your teachers and their interests. It’s possible that you may have teachers who don’t have much in common with you, and that makes it harder to find a connection or build one. If that’s the case, talk to your teacher about something interesting about their class, and go from there.

Here’s what my wife says (and she’s a teacher):— You really don’t know what teachers are like as a person. You really don’t know how they will take to this or that student. Teachers have a high-pressured job that doesn’t look like one. They’re under continual stress and a lot of their behaviours towards others are actually quite unpredictable.That being the case, avoid trying to seek likability. I’ve pretty much found out the same thing from my own schooldays over 40 years ago. I’m generally liked by teachers mainly because I try to stay in the ‘background’ and not be some kind of “classroom superstar” in either likability or dislikability.

The simple steps to be taken are :- Behave well in classroom.Be regular to his/her class.Just smile and wish them whenever u see them outside the class.Keep asking doubts about the subject and be attentive in class too.Never get caught in any of the controversial issues.

It depends on the teacher. Having a favourite is not an act of will. The teacher does not consciously like someone more than others, it’s a thing of the heart (a thing of the heart does not mean romantic, by the way). In general, it’s hard for a teacher to like someone that is rude or insolent. Other than that, it’s unpredictable. Even interaction does not determine who the teacher likes or does not like. The teacher sees more than the students think he/she sees. Don’t take it personally, just remember that teachers are humans too. I once liked a student because she reminded me of my sister when my sister was her age; I couldn’t help it, and neither could the student. I don’t even know whether the student particularly liked me or not. I don’t really care because it was at the time, and still is, irrelevant. It’s not like I’m going to adopt her.

I think for a teacher every student is its favorite student. The only thing is reaction,if a teacher react very softly with a weak student or very harshly with a bright student then it is definitely unfair. To help in improving the performance of a weak student, teacher has to become strict.And to boost the performance of bright student,teacher has to encourage him. So ,the point is study as hard as you can and forget about becoming teacher’s favorite student.

Come to class on time, every class period. Don’t leave early. Let the teacher know if you have a legitimate reason to miss class (before you miss, if the event is known in advance). Pay attention and do your work in class. If there is homework assigned, do the homework on time. Be genuinely interested in the subject. Be polite. I guess most of this is pretty typical advice. Beyond that, it depends on what level of education you are in and the individual teacher. Some teachers may enjoy staying after class to chat with students, while others want to leave, but are polite and will talk to you. I will say that being an A student or the best academically does not guarantee a student is among my favorites a given semester.

Unlike parents, teachers can have favorites. Although a teacher won't volunteer favorites to the class, because it can hurt feelings, there are favorites and they are based on students showing the following: RespectShowing initiativeBeing a mediatorCurving classroom Dynamics in the direction the teacher wantsA moral leaderOne student can make or break a classroom. If a popular student is remarkable and sides with the teacher, it can be a fantastic learning environment. That student is a favorite. Readersselect.com

It's no use trying to impress your teacher with any sort of motive. In fact, this kind of an intention should not cross your mind ever. The best way you'll be able to help yourself will automatically appeal to your teacher that is to say be a genuine person dear. Self disciplining yourself, whether it's concerning your studies, behaviour, work, conduct or any aspect will make you a likeable person. Respect your teacher, display good manners, use magic words, try to be meticulous, focus on your studies, abide by the rules and remember by following all this you are helping yourself more than learning to impress your teacher. Teachers are proud of their kids anyways. Every child is unique. Explore your uniqueness :)

Being favourite of someone is not really much dependent on you. It is about how the other person's mentality is like. But with the above mentioned ways you can atleast try your best. Be yourself and don't fake or butter him, because in the long run that will take you away from the 'favorite' position when he realizes. Good Luck!

Teachers love it when students ask doubts or ask questions about a particular subject. when a particular student asks more doubts and questions, the teachers loves answering the questions. It creates a special bond between the teacher and the student.  Teachers love this kind of stuffs. I'm a favorite of my English teacher because I answer all of his questions before anyone and argue about some meanings in front of the whole class. Unfortunately, I lose most of the time XP.  He gives my advices too..  P.S. I know I'm very bad at explanations. But I'm working on it. XD

Trying to be a teacher’s favorite student is a waste of your time. Spend your time learning, studying, and helping or collaborating with other students. Do good things because it’s the right thing to do not to gain any favors with anyone. Most teachers prefer students who are honestly interested in learning, want to excel, and who sincerely are kind and care about others and themselves.

Go above and beyond. If you get perfect grades, then help others in class so they can, too. If you get feedback or grades you don’t agree with, figure out what you could have done better and think before you talk to the teacher about it. Be humble - that means (to me) to be teachable. Avoid being a know it all. If you know stuff, that’s great, but what don’t you know? Ask that of yourself more. Help others in class. If you can’t - if the class is over your head - then seek help from others. In that sense you are helping others, because they will learn from helping you, and it will likely make them feel good about themselves.

Nothing better than to have a teacher’s pet. I would like to have all 34 students in my classroom to be a teacher’s pet because a teacher’s pet wants to please a teacher by doing everything they possibly can to show the teacher they have an appreciation for her subject matter and will do whatever it takes to get good grades by studying, asking and answering questions, completing all assignments and going above and beyond!

A ‘teacher’s pet’ is usually made by the jealousy of other students who do not work as hard, engage in the class as well, study as conscientiously, or do as well as the student(s) of whom they can only make fun by calling them names. Teachers appreciate students who make an effort to work hard, study, engage with them and the class, and are conscientious about doing well. Slackers resent that, so they call names because that is the best childish minds can do.

Well there is nothing called teacher’s favorite student. It totally depends on you how you are seeking attention of the teacher towards you. If you will work hard then its quite obvious that the first preference for anything will become you by your teacher . But that doesn’t means you are a teacher’s favorite. Its your hard work and teacher’s dedication towards you that makes you the right person to be respected. That respect people calls it ‘THE TEACHER’S MOST FAVORITE STUDENT’.

Okay, I’d say it depends on the teacher. I think a teacher's favourite should be intelligent (or willing to learn what he/she doesn’t know), respectful, a well-rounded person to teach and from which to learn. He /she should be motivated too. And it’s a plus if they show that they sincerely care for their teacher. Or they can also remind the teacher of someone in their lives.

You can become one of my favorite students by coming back to visit years later and either telling me how critical my homework was to your success in life, how you’re now rich because of the influence of my rigorous curriculum and want to give me a grant for educational purposes, or by giving me any kind of useful constructive criticism.

It’s not necessary to get very good marks, but being sincere in your studies and showing interest in it.Plus, even if you don’t attend classes daily, be more or less regular and punctual.Maintain decorum in the classroom.Last but not the least, have your own principles and ideals and try to stick to them; this can make you anybody’s favourite.

Keep up with your school work.Always make sure that your teachers feel like they have been missed.Always keep your supplies organised.Be punctual.Don't go overboard.Be polite!Never gossip about the teacher to your friends.Ask questions!

For me, the students that are the most likable are those who use basic manners. It has nothing to do with how smart you are. I have had bright students with impeccable manners, but I’ve also had weak students with impeccable manners. They don’t have to like me, or stand out academically. One girl said ‘Good Morning’ - every time she entered the classroom, and ‘Thank you’ every time she left, for the entire year I taught her. I actually looked forward to having her class, particularly if things weren’t going outside the classroom.

Work hard!!! Have a good attitude. Ask questions if you do not understand. Make an effort to be kind to other students, especially those who are needy. Show your appreciation with a smile . Talk to your teacher when the opportunity arises. Be of help to your teacher if you can. Finally, behave properly and obey the rules. If you do these things, you will be an absolute favorite of any teacher.

simple straight forward answer respond to questions which they askask doubtsmanage the class before she comessometimes buttering like mam your dress is looking very pretty (my classmate did he got 30/30 in practical i got only 29 but doesn’t matter)perform well in test, half - yearly and yearly examsNOTE - don’t do too much buttering teachers are smart

Just react to your teacher questions even if it's wrong also you should say confident whenever she ask any question you should be the first guy to answer the question then she will get an impression on You

Instead of buttering your teachers, try to place yourself in her/ his position and know why they treat you like that! You have the ability to be a good or bad student. Your actions lead to results in positive or negative way. Mr. Rajeev Anand has explained in detail.

Easy! Ask questions that go deeper than the curriculum. Find interesting facts, discoveries, and questions outside of class and share during the class time. Allow the teacher to delight in your interest. You will be amazed at the results.
